Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: My phone buzzed violently on the nightstand, jolting me awake. It was 2:13 a.m. I squinted at the screen—my best friend’s name glowed. I answered, and immediately heard sobs. She could barely speak, but I caught enough: her father had collapsed, and she was terrified. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to find the right words, to be the steady presence she needed. But as I listened, my work phone rang. I’d forgotten about the late shift, covering for a sick coworker. The caller ID flashed: Mr. Jenkins, a notoriously difficult customer. I hesitated, torn. If I ignored him, I’d risk a formal complaint and maybe my job. If I answered, I’d have to switch gears, mask my worry, and handle his barrage of questions about our latest offer—he’d want details, reassurances, patience. My friend’s sobs grew louder in my ear. I felt split in two, the weight of her pain and his demands pressing on me, each expecting my full attention, my empathy, my professionalism. My hands shook as I stared at both phones, caught between being the friend she needed and the employee my boss expected.
